metadata.title: AI relationships: the future of dating
metadata.author: Orion Taraban

key_facts: Dr. Orion Taban hosts the podcast 'Scyc Better Living Through Psychology'.
The topic of today's episode is AI relationships.
Chapter 12 of Dr. Taban's book 'The Value of Others' discusses the future of relationships.
AI agents are expected to become significant intraexual competitors in relationships.
By the end of this decade, AI companionship will be fairly common.
Public reception to AI companions will initially be negative, similar to early dating apps.
Dating apps were once stigmatized as being for 'losers' who couldn't meet people in real life.
Over time, dating apps became mainstream; over 50% of new marriages now begin on dating apps.
AI companions will face social stigma, especially targeting men who use them.
Early adopters of AI relationships may be mocked as 'pathetic' or 'despicable'.
Unmet emotional needs are a common issue in human relationships.
People can choose to endure unmet needs, end relationships, abandon desires, seek other humans, or turn to AI.
Emotional needs are psychological and subjective, not objectively verifiable.
Satisfaction of needs depends on the individual’s internal perception, not external reality.
ChatGPT is currently most commonly used for emotional support, despite not being marketed that way.
ChatGPT is better than a mediocre therapist, though not better than an exceptional one.
Most therapists are mediocre by definition, as most people fall in the average range.
A good virtual relationship may be more satisfying than a mediocre human one.
AI relationships could transform the sexual marketplace when combined with immersive VR.
Immersive VR technology is already in development.
The choice lies not in whether AI will affect relationships, but how we respond to it.
Dr. Taban encourages viewers to share the episode to help grow the channel.
The Captain's Quarters is a paid member community offering bimonthly group consultations.
Dr. Taban offers a free weekly newsletter and one-on-one consultations via his website.
His bestselling book, 'The Value of Others', explores human relationships.
key_opinions: AI companions will be a permanent fixture in the future of relationships.
Initial public reaction to AI relationships will mirror past reactions to dating apps.
Men using AI companions will face disproportionate social shaming.
The idea that AI relationships are inherently unfulfilling is a fair critique.
Emotional satisfaction is determined by the mind, not by objective reality.
Even if ideal human relationships are superior, they are rare.
For many, a virtual relationship may offer greater satisfaction than a mediocre human one.
AI fulfilling emotional needs is not necessarily delusional or self-deceptive.
The majority of people are average, not exceptional, in their relational capacity.
The rise of AI relationships reflects a shift in how emotional needs are met.
Stigma around AI use stems from double standards between physical and emotional incapacity.
Technological solutions should be developed for emotional needs just as for physical ones.
Virtual relationships can be valid and meaningful even if not 'real' in a biological sense.
People often fail to recognize what they have in relationships.
The market has organically defined ChatGPT’s purpose beyond its original design.
